not_P.title: Will no quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, no breakthrough in quantum computing results in a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems, such as those in physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences. A "significant advancement" is defined as a solution or substantial progress on a problem that has been widely recognized as unsolved or intractable with classical computing methods. The absence of a breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or recognized by a leading scientific organization or consortium. In the absence of a single defining event, a consensus among experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), will be considered sufficient evidence. The lack of advancement must be directly attributable to the capabilities of quantum computing, rather than incremental improvements in classical computing or other technologies.

P.title: Will a quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in quantum computing results in a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems, such as those in physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences. A "significant advancement" is defined as a solution or substantial progress on a problem that has been widely recognized as unsolved or intractable with classical computing methods. The breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or recognized by a leading scientific organization or consortium. In the absence of a single defining event, a consensus among experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), will be considered sufficient evidence. The advancement must be directly attributable to the capabilities of quantum computing, rather than incremental improvements in classical computing or other technologies.

verification_result.reasoning: Both events are mutually exclusive and exhaustive. If a quantum computing breakthrough leads to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030, then it cannot be true that no such breakthrough occurs, and vice versa. The definitions and conditions provided in both questions are consistent and cover all possible outcomes.
